I just thought about #javascript #flow: the annotations are removed in production, which could result in a dev using it for input validation
like (argument foo must be string), but when it's called later in production, the guard is no longer in place. Which could lead to unexpectd

behaviour.
So I'm thinking it might be better to use tcomb, which does runtime type checking, instead of inspection based type checking.
The tcomb checks can be removed with babel, but I think shouldn't because it provides a great solution for input validation.

Here is my observation on network organizations: they will need a new, full-blown role of The Networker. #futureofwork (ctd.)
Their job will be to facilitate connections in the network by looking at people, projects and communication to find potential for synergies.
Because in a network (like in any big organization) it is no longer possible to be aware of what is being done all the time.
The networker will tap into the data feed that is created by project tools, public communication, status updates and work with this data.
But the will also get to know the people and their ideas, their motivation and what they are trying to achieve for the customer.
This calls for a deeper understanding of the subject matter. The Networker will be a role that's an especially good fit for comb-shaped ppl.
These are generalists, but with high skills in communication and empathy.
The Networker will be a highly valuable role. Because they create new opportunities from existing resources.
It's different from classical business development, because that focuses on the customer facing outside.
Network organizations are no longer ONE business entity but span multiple businesses.
The networker also needs to get familiar with partners and what they bring to the product and how they are achieving their contribution.
@calibanatspace @dc7590 I'm pretty sure that this is not his official job description. Organizations need to realize that this is an actual job, not a side-role.

In the last 4+ years I've been active in Frankfurt, the city officials have schon nothing but eagerness to exploit tech & startups for PR. https://t.co/aTvfiF38gz
"joining forces" in a city where officials just looks for the next opportunity to shine in the flashlight means nothing.
We already have hundreds of events per year that are choked by the fallout of real estate developments and clientele policy.
In a big "market of opportunities" like Frankfurt the opportunist is winning, and they don't need to care about joint efforts.

One of my revelation from today's #leancampfrm session on #diversity was this: it's my choice which events I support. I can change that!

If I keep seeing too many white dudes, maybe I should go to events, where they are not the majority. 
E.g. @WTM_Frankfurt @techettes_ffm.

And by "going" I also mean, facilitating, organizing. 
Did you know that I translated a press release for #bcrm16 to promote it to refugees?
But none showed up. So the question is, what can we do as event organizers to be more appealing to minorities.
Maybe it's our network that greatly influences who learns about the events and communities we are part of.
And we can oy create connections between different networks if we act as a bridge.

Just opening a port and waiting for a connection is not enough.
(to stay in the network metaphor)
